content:
The "Commission on Closure and Relocation of the Lorton Correctional Complex Act" establishes a commission to oversee the closure and relocation of the Lorton Correctional Complex. The commission's duties include managing the process of closure and relocation. The Commission is tasked with developing a comprehensive plan to close the Lorton Correctional Complex by 2010 and recommend options for the use of the land. Additionally, they are to create a plan for new prison facilities within the District of Columbia to replace the existing ones. The Commission is responsible for developing a plan to close the Lorton Correctional Complex and recommend options for the land use. They are also tasked with identifying appropriate sites, financing strategies, and operational plans for new prison facilities in the District of Columbia. The new facilities are expected to focus on education, vocational training, and inmate rehabilitation. The Commission will recommend strategies to improve operations and safety at the Lorton Correctional Complex before its closure and the establishment of new facilities. The Commission, composed of 21 members appointed by various authorities, will include individuals with specific qualifications such as being a member of a local civic association or an employee of the Virginia Department of Corrections. The Commission, composed of 21 members appointed by various authorities, will include individuals with specific qualifications such as being a member of a local civic association, a chamber of commerce in northern Virginia, an employee of the Fairfax County Sheriff's Department, an employee of the Fairfax County Police Department, and an employee of the District of Columbia Department of Corrections. Members of the Commission appointed under subsection (a)(3) include the Director of the Bureau of Prisons and the Director of the District of Columbia Department of Corrections. Other members must be knowledgeable about the establishment of new prison facilities, with representation from the Mayor or City Council, a chamber of commerce, and employees of the District of Columbia Metropolitan Police Department. Membership continuation rules state that a member appointed due to government affiliation may continue for up to 30 days after leaving or joining government service, with exceptions for those who have served for at least 3 months. Each member of the Commission must serve for the life of the Commission and vacancies are filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term. Members do not receive additional compensation and a quorum consists of 11 members. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are elected by a majority vote. The Chairperson of the Commission is elected by a majority vote of the members. SEC. 5. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by them, paid at level III of the Executive Schedule. They can appoint staff without following competitive service rules, pay them according to relevant regulations, and hire temporary services. Federal agencies can provide staff upon request. The head of any Federal department or agency may detail personnel to the Commission on a reimbursable basis to assist in carrying out its duties under section 3. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 6. The Commission, under Section 6, has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, and secure information from US departments or agencies. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can accept gifts or donations. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, receive evidence, and secure information from US departments. They can also accept gifts or donations and use the United States mails. The Administrator of General Services provides administrative support services on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 7. REPORTS.

The Commission will submit interim reports to the Fairfax County Board of Supervisors, the Mayor of the District of Columbia, and Congress at the 6th and 12th month marks after the Act's enactment. A final report will be sent to the same parties within 18 months, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation or administrative actions.

SEC. 8. TERMINATION.

The Commission will dissolve 90 days after submitting the final report.

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION. An amount not to exceed $1,000,000 is authorized to carry out this Act.
